values.description:
## Purpose
This PR is aiming to eliminate some uncertainty about our style guide. This pull request is motivated by [this discussion](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-fuel-tools/pull-requests/46/model-list-headers/activity#comment-59398269) where it was discovered that some of us had a different understanding of what the style actually is.

The disagreement is about whether mutators start with `Set` or are nouns like accessors. In practice this is not consistent in the ignition projects. On `default` in `ign-cmake`, `ign-common`, `ign-gui`, `ign-math`, `ign-msgs`, `ign-rendering`, `ign-sensors`, `ign-tools`, `ign-transport` there are 132 header files with mutators starting with `Set`, and 197 header files that either don't have mutators or have a noun form.

## Changes in this PR

Since there is not a clear winner in the code base (132 with `Set`, 197 without) I've made this PR use the `Set` form and because @nkoenig has the authority to prescribe style and that appears to be his preference.

If you have thoughts about the style or a strategy for updating the codebase I believe discussion is welcome.

I also changed terms `Good` and `Bad` to be more objective: `Allowed`, `Not Allowed`.

## Commands Run
Count headers with `Set` used in a mutator:

```
find ign* -name "*.hh" -exec grep --color=auto -l -e "Set[a-zA-Z_]*(" "{}" "+" | wc -l
```

Count headers without a mutator starting with `Set`

```
find ign* -name "*.hh" -exec grep --color=auto -L -e "Set[a-zA-Z_]*(" "{}" "+" | wc -l
```

## Preview
http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=contrib_code&cat=development&branch=style_getters_setters
values.title: Style for getters setters

The disagreement is about whether mutators start with `Set` or are nouns like accessors. In practice this is not consistent in the ignition projects. On `default` in `ign-cmake`, `ign-common`, `ign-gui`, `ign-math`, `ign-msgs`, `ign-rendering`, `ign-sensors`, `ign-tools`, `ign-transport` there are 132 header files with mutators starting with `Set`, and 197 header files that either don't have mutators or have a noun form.

## Changes in this PR

Since there is not a clear winner in the code base (132 with `Set`, 197 without) I've made this PR use the `Set` form and because @nkoenig has the authority to prescribe style and that appears to be his preference.

If you have thoughts about the style or a strategy for updating the codebase I believe discussion is welcome.

I also changed terms `Good` and `Bad` to be more objective: `Allowed`, `Not Allowed`.

## Commands Run
Count headers with `Set` used in a mutator:

```
find ign* -name "*.hh" -exec grep --color=auto -l -e "Set[a-zA-Z_]*(" "{}" "+" | wc -l
```

Count headers without a mutator starting with `Set`

```

```

## Preview
http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=contrib_code&cat=development&branch=style_getters_setters
summary.html:
Purpose

This PR is aiming to eliminate some uncertainty about our style guide. This pull request is motivated by this discussion where it was discovered that some of us had a different understanding of what the style actually is.

The disagreement is about whether mutators start with Set or are nouns like accessors. In practice this is not consistent in the ignition projects. On default in ign-cmake, ign-common, ign-gui, ign-math, ign-msgs, ign-rendering, ign-sensors, ign-tools, ign-transport there are 132 header files with mutators starting with Set, and 197 header files that either don't have mutators or have a noun form.

Changes in this PR

Since there is not a clear winner in the code base (132 with Set, 197 without) I've made this PR use the Set form and because @nkoenig has the authority to prescribe style and that appears to be his preference.

If you have thoughts about the style or a strategy for updating the codebase I believe discussion is welcome.

I also changed terms Good and Bad to be more objective: Allowed, Not Allowed.

Commands Run

Count headers with Set used in a mutator:

find ign* -name "*.hh" -exec grep --color=auto -l -e "Set[a-zA-Z_]*(" "{}" "+" | wc -l

Count headers without a mutator starting with Set

find ign* -name "*.hh" -exec grep --color=auto -L -e "Set[a-zA-Z_]*(" "{}" "+" | wc -l

Preview

http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=contrib_code&cat=development&branch=style_getters_setters

values.description:
This adds a tutorial about controlling the appearance of a model. It documents parameters related to color and textures. At the end it has an example using SDF, an ogre script, and collada file.

**Preview**
http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=color_model&branch=color_model

values.description:
Before this fix, I was getting

```shell
Reading package lists... Done
Building dependency tree
Reading state information... Done
E: Unable to locate package \
E: Unable to locate package \
E: Unable to locate package \
E: Unable to locate package \
```

when running `sudo apt-get install $(sed 's:\ ::g' <<< $BASE_DEPENDENCIES) $(sed 's:\ ::g' <<< $GAZEBO_BASE_DEPENDENCIES)`. This pull request fixes that and also adds how to use \`GAZEBO\_MAJOR\_VERSION\`
values.title: Fix script that installs dependencies from environment variables

GAZEBO\_libraries -> GAZEBO\_LIBRARIES in CMake

Otherwise built plugin \(\*.so file\) has unresoved symbols when attempted to be loaded.

GAZEBO\_libraries -> GAZEBO\_LIBRARIES in CMake

Otherwise built plugin \(\*.so file\) has unresoved symbols when attempted to be loaded.
summary.html:
GAZEBO_libraries -> GAZEBO_LIBRARIES in CMake

Otherwise built plugin (*.so file) has unresoved symbols when attempted to be loaded.

values.description:
Added compiler flag for C++11 otherwise build fails.
Also changed order of add_library and target_link_libraries statements in CMakeLists because otherwise it doesn't when using "catkin build" instead of "catkin_make" (see https://answers.ros.org/question/224698/what-causes-a-library-so-to-be-copied-to-devellib/).
values.title: Added compiler flag for C++11 otherwise build fails.

summary.raw:
Added compiler flag for C++11 otherwise build fails.
Also changed order of add_library and target_link_libraries statements in CMakeLists because otherwise it doesn't when using "catkin build" instead of "catkin_make" (see https://answers.ros.org/question/224698/what-causes-a-library-so-to-be-copied-to-devellib/).
summary.html: Added compiler flag for C++11 otherwise build fails. Also changed order of add_library and target_link_libraries statements in CMakeLists because otherwise it doesn't when using "catkin build" instead of "catkin_make" (see https://answers.ros.org/question/224698/what-causes-a-library-so-to-be-copied-to-devellib/).

This is currently blocked by a gazebo PR.

values.description: CMAKE\_CXX\_FLAGS is a variable, not a list. So append needs to be done with spaces, whereas list\(APPEND \) would add a semicolon and break the build if CMAKE\_CXX\_FLAGS already contains something.
values.title: Use set() to add GAZEBO_CXX_FLAGS to CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS

summary.raw: CMAKE\_CXX\_FLAGS is a variable, not a list. So append needs to be done with spaces, whereas list\(APPEND \) would add a semicolon and break the build if CMAKE\_CXX\_FLAGS already contains something.
summary.html: CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS is a variable, not a list. So append needs to be done with spaces, whereas list(APPEND ) would add a semicolon and break the build if CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS already contains something.

values.description:
The ROS plugin tutorial has an incorrect usage of the `${prefix}` variable in the gazebo\_ros export tag in `package.xml`. `${prefix}` points to the directory containing `package.xml`. Under a normal ROS installation, this is `/opt/ros/<distro>/share/<package_name>`. Therefore, the correct path to the `lib` directory is the somewhat ugly `${prefix}/../../lib`.

Some Gazebo plugin packages have copied this incorrect example \([turlebot3\_gazebo](https://github.com/ROBOTIS-GIT/turtlebot3_simulations/blob/master/turtlebot3_gazebo/package.xml#L28)\), but many others do not export anything at all. This seems to indicate that under a normal installation, the correct path is added to the search path through some other means, which has prevented anyone from noticing the mistake.
values.title: Fix example usage of ${prefix} in gazebo_ros export tag.

summary.raw:
The ROS plugin tutorial has an incorrect usage of the `${prefix}` variable in the gazebo\_ros export tag in `package.xml`. `${prefix}` points to the directory containing `package.xml`. Under a normal ROS installation, this is `/opt/ros/<distro>/share/<package_name>`. Therefore, the correct path to the `lib` directory is the somewhat ugly `${prefix}/../../lib`.

Some Gazebo plugin packages have copied this incorrect example \([turlebot3\_gazebo](https://github.com/ROBOTIS-GIT/turtlebot3_simulations/blob/master/turtlebot3_gazebo/package.xml#L28)\), but many others do not export anything at all. This seems to indicate that under a normal installation, the correct path is added to the search path through some other means, which has prevented anyone from noticing the mistake.
summary.html:
The ROS plugin tutorial has an incorrect usage of the ${prefix} variable in the gazebo_ros export tag in package.xml. ${prefix} points to the directory containing package.xml. Under a normal ROS installation, this is /opt/ros/<distro>/share/<package_name>. Therefore, the correct path to the lib directory is the somewhat ugly ${prefix}/../../lib.

Some Gazebo plugin packages have copied this incorrect example (turlebot3_gazebo), but many others do not export anything at all. This seems to indicate that under a normal installation, the correct path is added to the search path through some other means, which has prevented anyone from noticing the mistake.
